S0926-860X(17)30563-X 10.1016/j.apcata.2017.12.009 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts: (A) Reduced, (B) Used. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 H2−TPR profiles of calcined alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of reduced alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts: (A) Ce 3d, (B) Co 2p3/2 and (C) O 1s. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 CO conversion with reaction temperature over alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts (H2O/(CH4 + CO + CO2) = 2.0; GHSV = 143,000 h−1). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 CO conversion with time-on-stream over alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts (H2O/(CH4 + CO + CO2) = 2.0; T = 450 °C; GHSV = 143,000 h−1). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM images of Co/CeO2 calcined (a) and used (b), BaCo/CeO2 calcined (c) and used (d), CaCo/CeO2 calcined (e) and used (f), KCo/CeO2 calcined (g) and used (h), and NaCo/CeO2 calcined (i) and used (j) catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Particle size distribution of alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts measured from TEM images. Fig. 7 Table 1 Characteristics of alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. Rode b Byong-Hun Jeon c Jong Wook Bae d Hyun-Seog Roh a ⁎ a Department of Environmental Engineering, Yonsei University, 1 Yonseidae-gil, Wonju, Gangwon 26493, South Korea Department of Environmental Engineering Yonsei University 1 Yonseidae-gil Wonju Gangwon 26493 South Korea b Chemical Engineering & Process Development Division, CSIR National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411008, India Chemical Engineering & Process Development Division CSIR National Chemical Laboratory Pune 411008 India c Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Engineering, Hanyang University, 222 Wangsimni-ro, Seongdong-gu, Seoul 04763, South Korea Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Engineering Hanyang University 222 Wangsimni-ro, Seongdong-gu Seoul 04763 South Korea d School of Chemical Engineering, Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU), 2066 Seobu-ro, Suwon, Gyeonggi 16419, South Korea School of Chemical Engineering Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU) 2066 Seobu-ro Suwon Gyeonggi 16419 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract We prepared a series of alkali (Na and K) and alkaline earth metal (Ca and Ba) promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts to investigate the effect of the promoter on the catalytic performance of the catalyst in the high-temperature water-gas shift (WGS) reaction of waste derived synthesis gas. Interestingly, alkali metal promoted catalysts deactivated rapidly compared to alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts. Alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts showed relatively higher stability (> 50 h) even at a very high gas hourly space velocity of 143,000 h−1. X − ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) results reveal that the higher stability of the alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts was due to the strong resistance to sintering, showing a relatively small crystallite size of metallic cobalt compared to the alkali metal promoted catalysts after WGS reaction. Keywords Waste derived synthesis gas High temperature water-gas shift Alkaline earth metal Co/CeO2 Stability Sintering resistance 1 Introduction Hydrogen gas is applied as a fuel, particularly in polymer-electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), for the generation of electrical energy in an environmentally friendly manner [1]. The only products emitted by fuel cells that use hydrogen are heat and water. Hydrogen is produced from several sources, including natural gas (48%), oil (30%), coal (18%), and water electrolysis (4%) [2], but there is a clear dependence on fossil fuels for hydrogen production (96% of the total amount produced) and this dependence severely limits the use of hydrogen as an energy vector. Current research must explore renewable resources for the production of hydrogen that can minimize its environmental impact and cost, thereby allowing hydrogen to become a widely used source of energy. Municipal solid waste (MSW) is one of the most abundant renewable resources in the world, and could be employed for the sustainable production of hydrogen by gasification of MSW (MSW-derived synthesis gas), which consists of CO and H2 with relatively low concentrations of CO2, CH4, N2, solid carbon (C), and some traces of tar [3,4]. The production of high-purity hydrogen from waste-derived synthesis gas requires integration of the WGS reaction with MSW gasification: CO + H2O → CO2 + H2, in which CO is eliminated, and hydrogen is added to the output gas. The WGS reaction is performed in two steps because of thermodynamic limitations, i.e., a high-temperature shift (HTS; 300–500 °C) over Fe2O3–Cr2O3 followed by a low-temperature shift (LTS; 180–250 °C) over CuO–ZnO–Al2O3 catalysts [5]. It would be desirable to use the HTS reactor in hydrogen production through waste gasification because the outlet temperature of the waste gasifier is commensurate to the HTS temperature range. The active phase in the commercial Fe2O3–Cr2O3 catalyst for HTS is Fe3O4; Cr2O3 works as a textural promoter to prevent the loss of specific surface area of the Fe3O4 [6]. Thus, extreme care is required during the reaction to avoid the formation of metallic Fe by over-reduction, which may catalyze some undesirable reactions [7]. In addition, Cr is environmentally hazardous and carcinogenic. The operational challenges involved in the use of the commercial Fe2O3–Cr2O3 catalyst have necessitated studies to develop Cr- and Fe-free HTS catalysts. In recent years, our group have explored non-noble transition metal based HTS catalysts to produce hydrogen using waste-derived synthesis gas [4,5,8–10]. As ceria-based catalysts have been widely studied in water-gas shift catalysis field due to its unique redox property [4,8–9,11–18], we also discovered a ceria supported cobalt-based catalyst for the HTS reaction [8]. The CoCeO2 catalyst showed higher activity and stability (XCO = 90% at 400 °C) than bare Co3O4 (XCO = 68% at 400 °C), and the metallic phase of cobalt was identified as the active phase for the HTS reaction. However, the stability study demonstrated that the CoCeO2 catalyst lost its catalytic activity after 30 h. The deactivation of the catalyst mainly occurs due to the deposition of carbonaceous species, loss of metallic surface area by particle growth, poisoning or oxidation of the metallic particles [19]. In our study, deactivation of the Co/CeO2 catalyst was attributed to the particle growth of metallic cobalt which may be induced by the weak interaction between dopants and ceria support. Many attempts have been made to stabilize the supported cobalt-based catalysts by the addition of dopants such as alkali and alkaline earth metals [20–22], which can reportedly act as textural or electronic promoters in catalytic processes [23]. Calles et al. have observed that the stability of the catalyst in glycerol steam reforming was improved by an alkaline earth metal based promoter because of lower coke deposition [22]. Flytzani-Stephanopoulos and co-workers proposed that the activity and stability of Pt supported on multi-walled carbon nanotubes catalysts in the WGS reaction was enhanced by the presence of Na atoms [24]. Kawi et al. found that doping ceria with alkali metals influenced the lattice strain, activating the lattice oxygen and thereby increasing the activity and selectivity of the catalyst [25,26]. Haneda et al. found that doping a Co3O4 catalyst with alkali metals weakened the CoO bond and promoted oxygen desorption from Co3O4, resulting in the formation of reduced cobalt species [27]. Research by Song and Ozkan found that incorporation of Ca in Co/CeO2 catalysts for ethanol steam reforming lead to increased oxygen vacancies, which in turn enhanced the oxygen mobility in ceria-supported Co catalysts [28]. The addition of alkali metals to cobalt oxide promoted the adsorption of CO on the catalyst surface, which enhanced the catalytic activity [29]. In this work, we focused on the development of alkali (Na, K) and alkaline earth metal (Ba, Ca) promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts with enhanced properties, including catalytic activity and long-term stability in the HTS reaction, which is an important goal for industrial applications. The activity results of the developed catalyst illustrated that alkali metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst showed slightly higher catalytic activity, whereas alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst showed extremely higher stability. The alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area determination by N2 adsorption/desorption, inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), H2−temperature programmed reduction (H2−TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) to investigate the origin of the significant stabilization of cobalt-based catalysts promoted by alkaline earth metals as compared to those promoted by alkali metals. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The 15 wt.% Co/CeO2 catalyst was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. Four promoted catalysts containing a promoter (2 wt.%) (Ba, K, Na, and Ca) and Co (15 wt.%) supported over CeO2 (83 wt.%) were prepared by an incipient wetness co-impregnation method. The CeO2 support was prepared by a precipitation method. In a typical synthesis, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solution (0.04 M) was precipitated by drop-wise addition of KOH solution (15 wt.%) at 80 °C with constant stirring to attain a pH of 10.5. The precipitate was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The as-obtained solid product was thoroughly washed with 2 L of distilled water. After filtration, the precipitate was dried at 100 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. The resulting CeO2 support was co-impregnated with nitrate precursors of the promoter and cobalt. Both nitrate precursors of cobalt (15 wt.%) and promoters (2 wt.%) were dissolved together in 0.5 mL of distilled water with the help of ultra-sonication and the prepared solution was impregnated over the 0.83 g (equivalent to 83 wt.% of CeO2) of calcined support. The impregnation process was performed repeatedly for 5–6 times to load all of the precursor solution. Between two successive steps, the sample was dried at 100 °C for 1 h in the oven. Finally, the obtained solid particles were air dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined in a furnace at 500 °C for 6 h before further characterization and activity tests. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X − ray diffractograms (XRD) of the reduced and used catalysts after stability test were recorded in a 2θ range of 20–80° using a Rigaku D/MAX-IIIC diffractometer (Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation, 40 kV, 100 mA). The crystallite size of the catalysts was estimated using the Scherrer equation. The unit cell parameter of the ceria was estimated by employing standard indexation methods using the intensity of the high 2θ peaks (111) at 2θ = 28.4°. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the catalysts was determined by the N2 adsorption/desorption method at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010. The elemental composition of alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) using ICP/IRIS, Thermo Jarrell Ash. The analysis results are shown in Table S1. FT-IR (Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy) spectra of the samples were collected using a Nicolet Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (NEXUS 470). For FT-IR measurements, the powder samples were mixed with IR-grade KBr powder and pressed into disks without any pretreatment. H2−TPR of the catalysts was measured on an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics) instrument. Typically, a sample (0.1 g) was loaded into a quartz reactor. H2−TPR was performed using 10% H2/Ar with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 50 to 800 °C. The sensitivity of the detector was calibrated by reducing a known weight of NiO. XPS measurements were performed on a Kα Thermo-Scientific spectrometer using a high-resolution monochromated Al-Kα X-ray source. All measured spectra were corrected by the reference binding energy of carbon (1s), which was set at 284.6 eV. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA/DSC 1 STARe system SF 1100) was conducted to study the amount of coke formed during reactions. A used sample after the stability test was collected and heated from 50 to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in oxygen. The morphologies of the alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts were measured by TEM using a TECNAI G2 instrument operated at 200 kV. In case of XRD and XPS, fresh catalysts were reduced in 5% H2/N2 at 400 °C (30 mL/min) for 1 h prior to analysis. Passivation process using 10% Air/N2 at room temperature for 6 h was followed before the exposure to air to avoid explosive oxidation. Calcined catalysts were used for BET, ICP-AES, FT-IR, H2-TPR, and TEM measurements. 2.3 Catalyst performance test Catalytic experiments were performed between 350–550 °C at ambient pressure in a fixed-bed micro-tubular quartz reactor with an inner diameter of 4 mm. The catalyst powder (0.03 g) was placed in the reactor, and quartz wool was used to hold the catalyst bed in a fixed position. The reactor was heated in a furnace, and a T-junction was employed at the exit of the quartz reactor to install a thermocouple. A thermocouple was inserted into the catalyst bed to measure the reaction temperature. The temperature was programmed to increase in steps of 50 °C from 350 °C to 550 °C. Considering the time until the gas reaches the micro gas chromatograph (Agilent 3000) after the reaction occurred at the catalyst bed, the temperature and the flow rate of inlet gas were held it about 30 min in each step. After that, the catalysts were tested 5 times with a 3 min time interval in 20 min and the average values of CO conversion in each temperature are provided in Fig. 4. Before each catalytic measurement, the catalyst was reduced by heating in 5% H2/N2 from room temperature to 400 °C at a heating rate of 4.6 °C/min and maintaining the temperature for 1 h. Afterward, the temperature was decreased to 350 °C. The reaction gas mixture consisted of CO (17.02 vol.%), CO2 (9.55 vol.%), CH4 (1.03 vol.%), H2 (13.14 vol.%), H2O (55.20 vol.%), and N2 (4.06 vol.%), which represents a typical syngas output from a waste gasifier that might enter the WGS reactor in a waste gasification system. The feed ratio of H2O/(CH4+CO+CO2) was intentionally fixed at 2.0 to avoid coke formation. A gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 143,000 h−1 was used to screen all the prepared catalysts. Water was fed using a syringe pump and vaporized at 180 °C upstream of the reactor. The outlet gas was chilled, passed through a trap using drierite® to condense residual water, and then the reactants and products were analyzed online using a micro gas chromatograph (Agilent 3000). The conversion of CO and the selectivity of CO2 and CH4 were calculated using the following formulas. C O c o n v e r s i o n % = [ C O ] i n - [ C O ] o u t [ C O ] i n × 100 C O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y % = [ C O 2 ] o u t - [ C O 2 ] i n ( [ C H 4 ] o u t - [ C H 4 ] i n ) + ( [ C O 2 ] o u t - [ C O 2 ] i n ) × 100 C H 4 s e l e c t i v i t y % = [ C H 4 ] o u t - [ C H 4 ] i n ( [ C H 4 ] o u t - [ C H 4 ] i n ) + ( [ C O 2 ] o u t - [ C O 2 ] i n ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD and BET Fig. 1 (A) shows the XRD patterns of the reduced alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. The major diffraction lines in all the promoted catalysts were consistent with the fluorite-type oxide structure of CeO2. A small diffraction peak at 2θ = 44.2° was observed in all the catalysts, corresponding to the fcc phase of Co° [8]. The CaCo/CeO2 catalyst showed a small peak of Ca° at 2θ = 41.0° (JCPDS 10-0348). The BaCo/CeO2 catalyst showed a small peak at 38.7° that corresponded to BaO (JCPDS 47-1488). The peaks correspond to alkali metal was not detected. This implies that the alkali and alkaline earth metal promoter was uniformly dispersed over the CeO2 matrix. Fig. 1(B) shows the XRD patterns of the used catalysts after stability test. The peak intensity of Co° has increased except in the BaCo/CeO2 catalyst. In addition, Na° peak (JCPDS 09-0188) has formed in NaCo/CeO2 catalyst after HTS reaction. Scherrer equation was applied to determine the crystallite size of the prepared catalysts using the diffraction peak of Co° at 2θ = 44.5° (111). The estimated values are shown in Table 1 , demonstrating the increase in crystallite size of Co° after HTS reaction. Table 1 shows the surface area (SBET) values of the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. The SBET of promoted catalysts were decreased as compared to the non-promoted Co/CeO2. Among the promoted catalysts, the alkaline earth metal promoted samples showed higher surface areas than the alkali metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. 3.2 FT-IR FT-IR spectra of the alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts were recorded in the region of 4000–400 cm−1 to analyze the structure of the catalysts. Fig. S1 shows a broad band at ∼3365 cm−1, which originates from the stretching vibration of OH bonds. These OH bonds are often accompanied by a band located at ∼1640 cm−1 [30]. This band occurred at 1627 cm−1 in the FTIR spectra of the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. All promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts displayed two sharp bands at 572 cm−1 (v 1) and 665 cm−1 (v 2), originating from the stretching vibrations of the CoO bond of cobalt oxide [31]. The v 1 band is the characteristic vibration of Co3+ in octahedral holes, and the v 2 band is attributed to the vibration of Co2+ in tetrahedral holes [32]. The presence of these bands suggests that cobalt is present as Co3O4 in the calcined catalysts. 3.3 H2-TPR H2-TPR experiments were carried out to examine the influence of the alkali and alkaline earth metals on the redox properties of Co/CeO2 catalysts. The TPR profiles of the promoted catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The TPR profiles of alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts displayed two well-resolved reduction peaks in the temperature ranges of 200 − 305 °C and 310 − 450 °C, which can be attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co°, respectively [33]. The un-doped Co/CeO2 catalyst also showed two reduction peaks at 327, and 377 °C. The TPR peaks of the alkali metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst were shifted to higher temperature compared to the alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts. This result might be associated with the difference in the particle size of the catalysts. In the case of KCo/CeO2 catalyst, reduction peaks have shifted to higher temperatures with a significant broadening of the peak [34]. The reduction profile of NaCo/CeO2 catalyst showed a broad reduction peak between 300 − 500 °C, which was assigned to a single step reduction of Co3O4 to Co°. Luo et al. reported that large particles of Co3O4 are often reduced directly to Co° in one step, while smaller particles of Co3O4 that interact with the ceria are reduced in two steps [35]. 3.4 XPS XPS analysis of the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts was performed to explore the electronic structure of the catalysts, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 3 . The XPS spectra of Ce 3d in the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 3(A). The spectra of the reduced ceria were fitted to five sets of spin-orbit doublets. Previously reported results suggest the peaks labeled as vo, v, v’, v” and v”’ refer to 3d5/2 states, while the peaks labeled as uo, u, u’, u” and u”’ refer to 3d3/2 states. The peaks at positions vo, v’, uo and u’ were attributed to Ce3+, while the others were attributed to Ce4+ ions [36,37]. The spectral contribution of Ce3+ was estimated by the following equation: Ce3+ (%) = {(Av0  + Av’ + Au0  + Au’)/ ∑Ai}*100 Where, Ai is the combined area of all peaks. The concentration of Ce3+ ions in the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts is listed in Table 1. The results showed that doping Co/CeO2 catalysts with alkali metal promoters has limited effect on the concentration of Ce3+, while alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts exhibit relatively higher concentrations of Ce3+ ions. These higher concentrations were attributed to the reduction of the ceria support, induced by the transfer of electrons from the dopants: 2CeO2 + 2e− → Ce2O3. The formation of a higher concentration of reduced ceria species (Ce3+ ions) in alkaline earth metal promoted catalyst shows that there is a stronger interaction between cobalt, CeO2, and alkaline earth metal dopant, compared to alkali metal promoted catalysts [36]. This effect can also be seen from the results of the Co 2p3/2 and O 1s XPS spectra of the alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted catalyst shown in Fig. 3(B) and (C), respectively. The peak of the Co 2p3/2 binding energy (BE) appeared at 779 eV for all the samples, all of which could be deconvoluted into three main peaks and one satellite peak except for the peak for the BaCo/CeO2 catalyst. The three main peaks, corresponding to the higher, middle, and lower BE, were attributed to Co2+, Co3+, and Co°, respectively. Based on previously reported findings, the Co3+ (octahedral) and Co2+ (tetrahedral) peaks were assigned to the Co3O4 phase [38]. The Co2+ (octahedral) and Co2+ (satellite) peaks were assigned to CoO [39]. These peaks indicate the presence of Co3O4, CoO, and Co° species on the surface of the catalysts. The participation of the d-orbital of Ba in the BaCo/CeO2 catalyst caused the appearance of a peak at the BE of 779.6 eV, which was attributed to BaO [40]. Therefore, the Co 2p3/2 spectrum for the BaCo/CeO2 catalyst was deconvoluted into four peaks and one satellite peak. The O 1s spectra of the promoted catalysts shown in Fig. 3(C) were deconvoluted into three peaks corresponding to the different oxygen species present in the catalyst. These peaks can be assigned to the lattice oxygen (CoO/CeO, 528.9 ± 0.1 eV), oxygen that is closer to the oxygen vacancy sites (O2 2−/O−, 530 ± 0.3 eV), and adsorbed oxygen species from hydroxyl group or water on the surface (532 ± 0.2 eV) [36,38]. The BE of lattice oxygen atoms in promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts were shifted to lower values (528.9 ± 0.1 eV) compared to the non-promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts (529.2 eV) (Fig. 3). This shift in the BE indicates an increase in the ionic character of CeO/CoO bonds on doping the Co/CeO2 catalysts with alkali and alkaline earth metals [41]. The BE of the lattice oxygen in alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts was further shifted to lower values than that of the alkali metal promoted catalyst, which indicates its greater ionic character. The relative amounts of the different oxygen species were calculated by measuring the areas under the deconvoluted peaks. Since the oxygen defects were formed over the oxygen vacancy sites, calculation of the ratio of defect oxygen to lattice oxygen (O2 2−/O2−) can give information about the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. The results are summarized in Table 1. As per their Ce3+ ions concentrations, the alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts have a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies than alkali metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. Oxygen vacancies are the active participants in the WGS reaction, and facilitate the diffusion of lattice oxygen [42]. 3.5 Catalytic activity The HTS reaction was performed over alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts to investigate how these promoters influence the activity of the Co/CeO2 catalyst. The WGS activity profiles of the promoted and non-promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts are shown as a function of temperature in Fig. 4 . The H2 yields are also shown in Fig. S2. The WGS reaction is mediated either by associative or redox mechanisms. However, the redox path predominates at higher temperatures (>350 °C) in ceria-based catalysts [43]. The redox path involves adsorption of CO at the metal-support interface, followed by oxidation by atomic oxygen derived either from the support or H2O dissociation [42]. H2O is more difficult to be activated among those two WGS reactants because of its high thermodynamic stability [44]. The activity results showed that the promoted catalysts exhibited slightly higher activity than the non-promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst at lower temperatures (350 °C). This difference is suggested to result from the activation of H2O in the presence of alkali or alkaline earth metal promoters. However, the non-promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst showed similar activity with other promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts at high temperatures (400 − 550 °C), indicating that the temperature as well as promoter both affects the activation of H2O and thereby modifies the catalysts’ activity in the HTS reaction. The other possible cause of the higher activity of the Co/CeO2 catalyst at higher temperatures is the increase in oxygen mobility from bulk to the surface [28]. Fig. 4 shows that the conversion of CO increases with increasing temperature up to 400 °C, after which it decreases because of the thermodynamic limits of the WGS reaction at high temperature. Xu et al. have reported that the alkaline earth metal (Ca2+) act as Lewis acids to which water molecule coordinates via an oxygen atom, which induces polarity in the OH bond. The resulting polarized H2O molecule is very reactive and can attack CO to produce CO2 and H2 [45]. However, at high temperatures (>400 °C), it seems that the thermal energy is sufficient to either increase the oxygen mobility or dissociate the H2O molecule; in these cases, the promoter ceases to affect the catalyst activity. The non-promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst showed highest catalytic activity at 400 °C. However, the activity has decreased as the temperature increases. Among the promoted catalysts, alkali metal promoted catalysts exhibit higher activity than the alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts in the temperature range of 400–550 °C. Similar observations were reported by Peralta et al. for cobalt-based catalysts used for diesel soot oxidation [46]. 3.6 Reaction selectivity Methanation (CO + 3H2 → CH4 + H2O) is an undesirable side reaction in the WGS reaction because it consumes 3 moles of hydrogen by removing 1 mol of CO, which dramatically decreases the hydrogen yield [47]. We plotted the graph related to the reaction selectivity revealed by the production of CO2 and CH4 over the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts as a function of temperature to clarify the role of the promoter on the selectivity, as shown in Fig. S3. Related equations are mentioned at section 2.3. The selectivity was not influenced by the presence of the promoters over the entire temperature range except in the case of the BaCo/CeO2 catalyst, which showed a maximum of 3% CH4 selectivity at lower temperatures (350 °C). This CH4 selectivity gradually decreased with increasing temperatures. 3.7 Catalytic stability Long-term stability at elevated temperatures is crucial for the industrial application of the HTS reaction. Fig. 5 shows the stability results of the promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts at 450 °C and a GHSV of 143,000 h−1. The alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts exhibited excellent stability (XCO = ∼85%, 50 h) compared to the alkali metal promoted catalysts in a stability test. The NaCo/CeO2 and Co/CeO2 catalysts were rapidly deactivated within the first 20 h of testing (∼20% loss compared to the initial CO conversion). The KCo/CeO2 catalyst also deactivated slowly after the experimental run of 50 h (∼8% loss compared to the initial CO conversion). The XRD analysis of used samples after stability test was conducted to find the reason of catalyst deactivation (Fig. 1(B)). The increase rate of crystallite size of Co° after stability test is shown in Table 1. The un-doped Co/CeO2 catalyst showed the highest increase rate (75% ↑) among the prepared catalysts. The alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts showed relatively lower increase rate (Ba: 13% ↑, Ca: 21% ↑) compared to the alkali metal promoted catalysts (K: 57% ↑, Na: 56% ↑). As it is shown in Fig. 5, NaCo/CeO2 catalyst has tested only about 20 h due to its rapid deactivation. However, it showed similar increase rate with KCo/CeO2 catalyst which is tested about 50 h. This result indicates that the crystallite size of NaCo/CeO2 catalyst may increase easily compared to KCo/CeO2 catalyst. Considering the increase rate of crystallite size of prepared catalysts and stability test result, resistance to sintering is strongly related to the stability of alkali and alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. It can be concluded that alkaline earth metal promoters prevent the sintering of metallic cobalt nanoparticles. As a result, alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts showed stable catalytic performance. To verify the particle size of the calcined and used catalysts, TEM analysis was carried out (Fig. 6 ). The TEM images of all the calcined catalysts showed a mixed morphology of particles with rounded and cubic shapes. The morphology of the catalysts did not change after the HTS reaction. However, the TEM image of the used sample of NaCo/CeO2 exhibits end-to-end fusion of particles to form a bulk-like structure, which could be originated from the increased cobalt atom mobility on the support [48]. This may be concluded to the rapid particle growth of metallic cobalt nanoparticles of NaCo/CeO2 catalyst. The size distribution and average particle size of the promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst particles was calculated from measurements of the particles in the TEM images. The particle sizes of the calcined and used catalysts are compared in Fig. 7 . The Co/CeO2 catalyst showed the biggest particle size among the used catalysts, showing that the cobalt particle agglomerates easily without promoters during the HTS reaction. The alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts showed relatively smaller particle size compared to alkali metal promoted catalysts after HTS reaction. The NaCo/CeO2 catalyst showed the highest increase rate of particle size among the promoted catalysts, even the catalyst was tested only 20 h. This result is also well-matching with the XRD result of used catalysts (Fig. 1(B)), especially showing the formation of Na° peak after stability test. This indicates that the crystal growth of Co° and Na° occurs easily compared to other promoted catalyst, resulting to the rapid deactivation of NaCo/CeO2 catalyst. This is mainly due to the weak interaction between Na and Co° compared to other promoters. The KCo/CeO2 catalyst also showed a similar crystal growth trend with NaCo/CeO2 catalyst, evaluated by XRD and TEM analysis of used catalyst after HTS reaction for 50 h. As a result, it is clear that the alkaline earth metal enhances the resistance to sintering by interacting with the metallic cobalt. The XPS spectra of used samples after stability test is shown in Fig. S4. The concentration of metallic cobalt (active phase) of reduced and used catalyst were compared (Table S2). The concentration of metallic cobalt maintained similar amount, showing that the sintering does not affect the oxidation state of the cobalt. It has been reasonably established that sintering and carbon depositions are the major contributors to the deactivation of catalysts [49]. Thus, TGA analysis were conducted to check the carbon deposition of used catalysts (Fig. S5). In general, the weight loss above 400 °C is ascribed to the oxidation of coke to CO and CO2. However, there was no significant change in the weight, indicating that the carbon deposition was not the reason of the catalyst deactivation. In the present study, the promotional effect of alkali and alkaline earth metal to Co/CeO2 catalyst was compared. The alkali metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst showed slightly higher catalytic activity. However, they showed rapid deactivation compared to the alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. The alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalyst showed extremely stable catalytic activity due to the enhanced sintering resistance. The TGA study result also reveals that the deactivation is not due to the coke formation, clearly suggesting that the sintering is the main reason of the deactivation. In conclusion, alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts showed stable activity, maintaining the CO conversion over 85% for at least 50 h even in a very high GHSV of 143,000 h−1. 4 Conclusion We investigated the use of alkali and alkaline earth metals as promoters to enhance the catalytic performance of Co/CeO2 catalysts for the HTS reaction using waste derived synthesis gas. The alkali metal promoted catalysts showed relatively higher activity whereas alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts exhibited higher stability than un-doped Co/CeO2. However, alkali metal promoted catalysts deactivated rapidly compared to alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts. TEM and XRD results shows that the higher stability of the Ba- and Ca- doped Co/CeO2 catalyst was caused by the strong resistance to sintering of metallic cobalt nanoparticles. In conclusion, alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts showed stable activity, maintaining the CO conversion over 85% for at least 50 h even in a very high GHSV of 143,000 h−1. This result shows that alkaline earth metal promoted Co/CeO2 are promising catalysts for use in the industrial HTS reaction, and are superior to alkali metal promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts. coredata.dc:description: We prepared a series of alkali (Na and K) and alkaline earth metal (Ca and Ba) promoted Co/CeO2 catalysts to investigate the effect of the promoter on the catalytic performance of the catalyst in the high-temperature water-gas shift (WGS) reaction of waste derived synthesis gas. Interestingly, alkali metal promoted catalysts deactivated rapidly compared to alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts. Alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts showed relatively higher stability (> 50 h) even at a very high gas hourly space velocity of 143,000 h−1. X − ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) results reveal that the higher stability of the alkaline earth metal promoted catalysts was due to the strong resistance to sintering, showing a relatively small crystallite size of metallic cobalt compared to the alkali metal promoted catalysts after WGS reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of alkali and alkaline earth metal on Co/CeO2 catalyst for the water-gas shift reaction of waste derived synthesis gas
